sub_topic: Prove that the power set of a set is always larger than the set itself.
message_1: Let A be a set such that |A|=3. Find the cardinality of P(A) where P(A) is the power set of set A, and prove that |P(A)|>|A|.
message_2:
To find the cardinality of the power set P(A), we can use the formula |P(A)| = 2^|A|, where |A| is the cardinality of set A.

Since |A| = 3, we can substitute this value into the formula:

|P(A)| = 2^3 = 8

So, the cardinality of the power set P(A) is 8.

Now, we need to prove that |P(A)| > |A|. We already know that |A| = 3 and |P(A)| = 8. Comparing these two values, we can see that 8 > 3, which means |P(A)| > |A|. This proves that the cardinality of the power set P(A) is greater than the cardinality of set A.
